title: 106_hr332
content: The Act may be cited as the "OPIC Termination Act" and it terminates the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation will cease issuing insurance, guarantees, loans, and securities under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. It will also terminate risk-sharing arrangements and be abolished 180 days after the Act's enactment. Operations will be transferred to the Office of Management and Budget. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation will transfer its functions to the Office of Management and Budget, ceasing contracts and agreements while winding up its affairs. Title IV of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 will be repealed, with funds transferred upon the repeal's effective date. Upon the repeal of Title IV of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, any unexpended funds will be transferred to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget for use in the Corporation's functions. After contracts expire, remaining balances will be deposited in the Treasury. SEC. 3. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. Prior determinations, regulations, and contracts issued under the provisions of law before the repeal shall remain in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials or through legal processes. The repeal does not affect pending proceedings before the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation's functions will continue for pending applications, with orders and proceedings remaining in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials or through legal processes. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation's functions will continue for pending applications, with orders and proceedings remaining in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials or through legal processes. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is authorized to issue regulations for the orderly transfer of proceedings. The Act does not affect suits commenced before its repeal, and all such suits will proceed as if the Act had not been enacted. Liabilities incurred by or against the Overseas Private Investment Corporation will not abate due to the Act's enactment. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation's functions will continue for pending applications, with orders and proceedings remaining in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials or through legal processes. Any cause of action by or against the Corporation or its officers shall not abate due to the Act. Suits involving the Corporation will continue with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget as a party. Orders and actions of the Director will be subject to judicial review as if issued by the Corporation. Any statutory requirements relating to notice, hearings, action upon the record, or administrative review that apply to any function of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation shall apply to the exercise of such function by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. SEC. 4. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Section 5 of the United States Code is amended by removing references to the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. Additionally, amendments are made to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to reflect changes related to the OPIC Abolition Act. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation is removed from various sections of different acts, including the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 and the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. Amendments are made to redesignate certain subparagraphs and paragraphs in these acts. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation is removed from various sections of different acts, including the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 and the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. Amendments are made to redesignate certain subparagraphs and paragraphs in these acts, such as amending subsection (b) of Section 574 of the Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 1996. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation is removed from various sections of different acts, including the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 and the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. Amendments are made to redesignate certain subparagraphs and paragraphs in these acts. Amendments are made to section 9101(3) of title 31, United States Code, including the repeal of various provisions of law such as sections from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation Amendments Act of 1981 and the Taiwan Relations Act. Subsections from the Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Acts of 1990 and 1991 are also repealed. The Corporation Amendments Act of 1988, referenced in Public Law 100-461, will take effect 180 days after enactment.
